articles.headline: Home Prices Fell Faster in October
articles.snippet: The decline in home prices accelerated and spread to more regions of the country in October, according to new data.
articles.abstract: The decline in home prices accelerated and spread to more regions of the country in October, according to new data.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decline in home prices accelerated and spread to more regions of the country in October, according to data released Wednesday.

articles.headline: Inside Apple Stores, a Certain Aura Enchants the Faithful
articles.snippet: Apple’s stock skyrocketed 135 percent in 2007, and its sleek retail gadget emporiums are a large part of that  success.
articles.abstract: Apple’s stock skyrocketed 135 percent in 2007, and its sleek retail gadget emporiums are a large part of that  success.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was 2 o’clock in the morning but in the subterranean retailing mecca in Midtown Manhattan, otherwise known as the Apple store, it might as well have been midafternoon.

articles.headline: Bridging 2 Marriages and 4 Decades, a Large, Close-Knit Brood
articles.snippet: Of the Republican candidates, John McCain has the most children, yet they are largely absent from his campaign.
articles.abstract: Of the Republican candidates, John McCain has the most children, yet they are largely absent from his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before Senator John McCain steps in front of an audience at a presidential debate, his daughter Meghan makes sure his nose is properly powdered. And from the campaign bus, Ms. McCain blogs about New Hampshire through the prism of politics and fashion (“I helped Dad pick out some swank Timberland boots.”)

articles.headline: The Pogies: Envelope, Please
articles.snippet: Welcome to the third annual Pogie awards presentation. Formal attire is not required, but some measure of product improvement is.
articles.abstract: Welcome to the third annual Pogie awards presentation. Formal attire is not required, but some measure of product improvement is.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good evening, and welcome to the third annual Pogie awards! Let’s hear it for Rico and the band!

articles.headline: The $50 Ticket: A Lottery Boon Raises Concern
articles.snippet: Critics say that instant scratch-off games are more likely to contribute to problem gambling.
articles.abstract: Critics say that instant scratch-off games are more likely to contribute to problem gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the popularity of traditional lotteries waning across the country, many states are turning to instant games priced at $20, $30 and as high as $50 to lure new players and raise revenue.

articles.headline: A Global Trek to Poor Nations, From Poorer Ones
articles.snippet: Across the developing world, migrants move to other poor countries nearly as often as they move to rich ones.
articles.abstract: Across the developing world, migrants move to other poor countries nearly as often as they move to rich ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUAN GÓMEZ, Dominican Republic  The scrap-wood shanties on a muddy hillside are a poor man’s promised land.

articles.headline: Las Vegas Wins Big
articles.snippet: Revenue on the strip is rising, even as rival casinos worry.
articles.abstract: Revenue on the strip is rising, even as rival casinos worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sparkling gambling palaces that line the Las Vegas Strip are intended to disconnect visitors from the realities of ordinary life.

articles.headline: Major Retailers Feel the Squeeze From Consumers
articles.snippet: Once seemingly invincible marquee chains like Coach, Starbucks and Abercrombie & Fitch are settling for ho-hum growth this winter.
articles.abstract: Once seemingly invincible marquee chains like Coach, Starbucks and Abercrombie & Fitch are settling for ho-hum growth this winter.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s merchants began poring  or weeping  over holiday sales receipts Wednesday, a surprising pattern emerged: even brands that for years have inspired the undying devotion of shoppers felt the pinch of tightening wallets.

articles.headline: Judge Hands I.R.S. Victory in Tax Shelter
articles.snippet: A civil court has ruled that a popular tax-avoidance scheme known as Son of Boss was abusive and any deductions claimed for it were invalid.
articles.abstract: A civil court has ruled that a popular tax-avoidance scheme known as Son of Boss was abusive and any deductions claimed for it were invalid.
articles.lead_paragraph: A civil court has ruled that a popular tax-avoidance scheme known as Son of Boss was abusive and any deductions claimed for it were invalid, an important victory for the Internal Revenue Service in its battle against questionable tax shelters sold to wealthy individuals.
